thread.title: 6 Breakfast Foods That Are Low-Key Bad for You
thread.title_full: 6 Breakfast Foods That Are Low-Key Bad for You

author: Anonymous
title: 6 Breakfast Foods That Are Low-Key Bad for You
text:
Tweet Posted: Mon, 1/2/2017 - 6:25pm by Andi Hester 
It’s way harder than it should be to eat food that's good for you. Sure, you could go paleo or vegan , but for people don't want to spend 99 percent of their lives explaining their dietary restrictions and why it's important others follow suit, the difference between healthy and garbage food can be difficult to determine. Here are the breakfast foods you eat all the time that are low key not good for you. (As for what you should be eating, I don't know. I'm basically a hummingbird and I just drink smoothies.) 1. Orange Juice 
via GIPHY 
According to Modernhealthmonk.com (we have no idea about the legitimacy of the site it's just the first to pop up on Google), orange juice is slowly killing you. While that may sound a bit dramatic, orange juice is chock full of sugar which may add unwanted weight over time. It can also cause heartburn and some digestive issues. Need that Vitamin C? Get it from a multivitamin and be done with it. 2. Bagels 
via GIPHY 
Bagels are everywhere, so they can't be that bad for you, right? Perhaps they're not "slowly killing you" like those stealthy, murderous oranges, but bagels are made from refined wheat flour which means all the fiber and good stuff that make whole grains food for you are GONE. WITH THE WIND. Also one bagel is equivalent to about six slices of bread. So do yourself a favor and pass the bagel in favor of five slices of bread and consider yourself winning at the healthy life. (No, don't do that.) 3. Dried Fruit 
via GIPHY 
Before you tell Granny to GTFO if she tries to give you another box of raisins, hear me out. Not all dried fruits are bad. You just have to watch out for the ones with added sugar. Fruits have enough sugar on their own, but when you throw in more sugar, you're basically eating candy. So, like, just go eat candy. (Don't do that. That was a joke.) 4. Bran Muffin 
via GIPHY 
In theory, these B.M.-instigators are good for you. Ingredients aren't all that bad, they have some health benefits. But the issues comes with their size. One Trader Joe’s bran muffin is 140 calories, but the serving size is only half a muffin. A whole muffin would be 280 calories and 26 grams of sugar. By the way, WHO IN THEIR RIGHT MIND ONLY EATS HALF A MUFFIN? 5. Granola 
via GIPHY 
Granola is one tricky son of a breakfast. It looks healthy and tastes healthy, but it isn't. The reason? Sugar yet again. Most nutrition experts agree you want a breakfast high in protein and fiber to keep you feeling fuller longer. 6. Cereal 
via GIPHY 
Hashtag sad, hashtag why. But hashtag true, cereal ain't that great for you. ¾ cup of Kashi Crunch is 190 calories and 13 grams of sugar. In comparison, one cup of Lucky Charms has 14 grams of sugar. So the cereal you're reaching for thinking you're being all healthy could actually be worse than the treat of your youth. To avoid the spike in blood sugar and subsequent energy dip once the sugar rush is gone, try plain old oatmeal or just not eating ever again. I heard that's healthy. 
Distraught? Heartbroken? So are we. We could live off cereal and bagels forever but now what’re we supposed to do?! HM?! Let us know on Twitter @AndiHester !
